content.description: This is the rightmost bolt line on the south-facing buttress. Start with easy slab moves to the first bolt, then follow the right arÃªte of the buttress all the way to the top. It has varied and interesting moves throughout: cracks, underclings, laybacks, overhangs, and thin slabs. The crux seems to be getting over the final bulge before the anchors, on sharp crystals with terrible feet. A rest before the final bulge makes it a good candidate for an onsight.
content.protection: 12 bolts plus an anchor. The topo (yellow line) shows approximate locations for some of them.

content.description: Scramble up low angle rock to a (somewhat unnecessary) first bolt on a slab that cannot be seen from the ground. Climb past four more bolts on a band of rotten rock, pull a small overhang on jugs, and arrive at a slab for a no hands rest while trying to figure out how to pull the overhang before the top. Hint: it's the crux, a pretty stiff one too.
content.protection: 12 bolts plus anchors. The bolt at the crux (10th or 11th bolt) is a bit of a reach for me at 5'7" wing span. If you have shorter wing span, I'd recommend an extendo draw for the crux or be ready to make some hard moves above a good clipping stance just to get the bolt clipped.
content.location:
This is the middle route on the south facing buttress, between

Cutting Out

and

Under The Knife

.

content.description:
This is a two-pitch route. I only did the first pitch, and it was a great warm-up for the area. This route is the second bolt line from the left on the east-facing wall.

Pitch 1 (5.10b, 80 feet?): climb up good edges and knobs to a small roof, traverse slightly to the right under the roof, then make a step left to get over the roof. The rest of the route is easier but still enjoyable all the way to the anchors.

Pitch 2 (5.10b): continue climbing up on knobs from the anchors of pitch 1. Apparently it gets easier near the top.

To get down from the anchors of pitch 2, make two rappels.
content.protection: 11 bolts to the anchors for the 1st pitch. I can only assume it's about the same or less for the 2nd pitch.

content.description: This is the leftmost route on the east face of Switchblade. The first bolt is to the left of a crack. Climb up broken ramps aiming for a shallow, left-facing dihedral. Climbing out of the dihedral to the face above is supposed to be the crux, but the holds are still pretty small above the crux. The anchor is guarded by another heart-breakingly thin section. Get a good rest while you can.
Fun, blocky climbing up a crack leads upwards. When the crack peters out, gain the prow for a moment, and then cut back left to a thin crux near the top.
content.protection: 9? quickdraws plus something for the anchors.
content.location: This route is the left route on a prow that defines the crag (keep in mind this is not the furthest left route at the crag).

content.description: Climb the overhanging bulge on the left side of the prow. I found the crux a bit burly and tricky but well-protected. A second easier crux is found near the top. Make sure not to cut too far left onto ?Fintastic?.
content.protection: 9? quickdraws plus something for the anchors.
content.location:
This is the bolted line just right of

Fintastic

.

content.description: This spectacular line goes more-or-less up the center of the gently overhanging 'switchblade' formation. While there are some crispy bits that will continue to flake off, most of the climbing is on good rock. Being taller than 5'10" or having a large wingspan may prove advantageous in a few sections. I am 5'10" with a negative ape index and felt like there were some reaches close to my limit. Off the deck, you will encounter some 5.12 edging and may be tempted to use the feature left of the dihedral - I personally think that it climbs better without it, but do whatever makes you happy. After that, the difficulty backs off a tad until you encounter the roof. Delicate and technical climbing is required to work into the roof then some burl to get over it. Some 'thank God' jugs just over the roof help to keep the lactic acid in check. Easy and strenuous climbing ebbs and flows until your reach the redpoint crux, which is getting through the last two bolts to reach the anchors. In general, this has lots of jugs and patina edging bliss - well worth the hike.
content.protection: 20-23 bolts. On redpoint, you will likely skip 3 or 4. You can scramble up to belay beneath the route proper, but being lazy, we opted for belaying from the ground - not a bad idea IMO. Just make sure you have a 70 meter rope, and knot the ends!
content.location:
This route is two lines left of

Fintastic

and is recognizable by the line of bolts going through the obvious jog or break in the roof above.
